{{unreferenced|date=April 2018}} {{Nihongo|'''Nōtan'''|濃淡}} is a [[Japan]]ese [[design]] concept involving the play and placement of light and dark elements as they are placed next to the other in the [[Composition (visual arts)|composition]] of [[art]] and [[image]]ry.
==Uses== This use of light and dark translates shape and form into flat shapes on a two-dimensional surface. Nōtan is traditionally presented in [[paint]], [[ink]], or cut [[paper]], but it is relevant to a host of modern-day image-making techniques, such as [[lithography]] in [[printmaking]], and [[rotoscope|rotoscoping]] in [[animation]].
==See also== *[[Gestalt psychology]] *[[Yin and yang]] <!--[Image:notan071000.jpg]]-->
==References== *''Composition: A Series of Exercises in Art Structure for the Use of Students and teachers '' by [[Arthur Wesley Dow]] (1899)(1855) *''Notan: A Virtual Art Academy building block'' by [[Barry John Raybould, MA]] (2004/2010) [http://www.virtualartacademy.com/notan.html Course on Notan] *''Notan: The Dark-Light Principle of Design'' by [[Dorr Bothwell]] and [[Marlys Mayfield]] (1968/1991) *''The Interaction of Color'' by [[Josef Albers]] (1963 ) *''Perception and Imaging'' by [[Richard D. Zakia]] (1997/2001)
==External links== * [http://artcafe.net/?p=117 Notan: Design in Light and Dark by Sharon Himes] (broken link)
[[Category:Japanese art]] [[Category:Printmaking]] [[Category:Design]] [[Category:Painting techniques]]

{{Multiple issues| {{peacock|date=November 2011}} {{more footnotes|date=November 2011}} }}
[[File:A Story-teller reciting from the "Arabian Nights." (1911) - TIMEA.jpg|thumb|A Story-teller reciting from the "Arabian Nights" - 1911]] [[File:Indian Kathakar Storyteller 1913.jpg|thumb|''Vyasa'' (sitting on high table), the common title for Indian oral storytellers, reciting epics among villagers, 1913]] '''Oral [[storytelling]]''' is an ancient and intimate [[tradition]] between the storyteller and their audience. The storyteller and the listeners are physically close, often seated together in a circular fashion.<ref>Hodge, F.S., Pasqua, A., Marquez, C.A., & Geishirt-Cantrell, B. (2002). Utilizing traditional storytelling to promote wellness in American Indian communities.</ref> Through the telling of the story people become psychically close, developing a connection to one another through the communal experience. The storyteller reveals, and thus shares, him/her self through his/her telling and the listeners reveal and share themselves through their reception of the story. The intimacy and connection is deepened by the flexibility of oral storytelling which allows the tale to be moulded according to the needs of the audience and/or the location or environment of the telling. Listeners also experience the urgency of a creative process taking place in their presence and they experience the empowerment of being a part of that creative process. Storytelling creates a personal bond with the teller and the audience.
The flexibility of oral storytelling extends to the teller. Each teller will incorporate their own personality and may choose to add characters into the story. As a result, there will be numerous variations of a single story.<ref>Silko, L. Storyteller. New York, New York: Seaver Books Pub., 1981</ref> Some tellers consider anything outside the [[narrative]] as extraneous while other storytellers choose to enhance their telling of the tale with the addition of [[visual]] and [[Sound recording and reproduction|audio]] tools, specific actions and creative strategies and devices.
Storytelling may be performed in many forms: in prose, in poetic form, as a song, accompanied with dance or some kind of theatrical performance, etc.
==Human need== [[File:The Childrens Museum of Indianapolis - Storyteller Under Sunny Skies clay sculpture.jpg|thumb|left|"Storyteller Under Sunny Skies," a clay sculpture by Rose Pecos-Sun Rhodes (Jemez Pueblo), 1993, in the permanent collection of [[The Children’s Museum of Indianapolis]]]] It is likely that oral storytelling has been around as long as human [[language]]. Storytelling fulfills the need for human beings to cast their experiences in narrative form. Our ancestors probably gathered around the evening fires and expressed their fears, their beliefs and their heroism through oral [[narrative]]s. This long tradition of storytelling is evident in ancient [[cultures]] such as the [[Australian Aborigines]]. Community storytelling offered the security of explanation; how life and its many forms began and why things happen, as well as entertainment and enchantment. Communities were strengthened and maintained through stories that connected the present, the past and the future.
Telling stories is a nurturing act for the listener, who is connected to the storyteller through the story, as well as for the storyteller who is connected to the listeners through the story.
==History== [[File:Dastangoi dastango.jpg|thumb|An Indian traditional oral storytller [[Dastangoi]] artist reciting the "Dastan"]]
Early storytelling probably originates in simple chants {{citation needed|date=August 2014}}. People sang chants as they worked at grinding corn or sharpening tools. Our early ancestors created myths to explain natural occurrences. They assigned superhuman qualities to ordinary people, thus originating the hero tale.
Early storytelling combined stories, poetry, music, and dance. Those who excelled at storytelling became entertainers, educators, cultural advisors, and historians for the community. Through storytellers, the history of a culture was handed down from generation to generation.
The importance of stories and storytellers throughout human history can be seen in the respect afforded to professional storytellers.
The 9th century fictional storyteller [[Scheherazade]] of ''[[One Thousand and One Nights]]'', who saves herself from execution by telling tales, is one example illustrating the value placed on storytelling in days of old. Centuries before Scheherazade, the power of storytelling is reflected by [[Vyasa]] at the beginning of the Indian epic ''[[Mahabharata]]''. [[Vyasa]] says, "If you listen carefully, at the end you'll be someone else."
In the [[Middle Ages]] storytellers, also called a troubadour or a minstrel, could be seen in the market places and were honored as members of royal courts. [[Medieval]] storytellers were expected to know all the current tales and in the words of American storyteller [[Ruth Sawyer]], ‘to repeat all the noteworthy theses from the universities, to be well informed on court scandal, to know the healing power of herbs and simples (medicines), to be able to compose verses to a lord or lady at a moment's notice, and to play on at least two of the instruments then in favor at court.’ According to some writers there were 426 minstrels employed at the wedding of Princess Margaret of England in 1290. Two of the storytellers of the court of [[King Edward I]] were two women who performed under the names of Matill Makejoye and Pearl in the Egg.
Journeying from land to land, storytellers would learn various regions's stories while also gathering news to bring back with them. Through exchanging stories with other storytellers, stories changed, making it difficult to trace the origins of many stories.
In the 1800s Jakob and Wilhelm [[Brothers Grimm|Grimm]] collected and published stories that had been told orally in [[Germany]]. They did not publish them as they found them however, but edited them in accordance with their own values. Like the Grimm brothers in Germany, [[Peter Christen Asbjørnsen]] and [[Jorgen Moe]] collected [[Norwegians|Norwegian]] folk tales. In Denmark [[Hans Christian Andersen]] adapted folktales he heard from oral storytellers. In England, [[Joseph Jacobs]] recorded collections of folktales of [[England]], [[Scotland]], [[Wales]].
In the 1900s the importance of oral storytelling was recognised by storytellers such as [[Marie Shedlock]], a retired English schoolteacher. She made several tours to the [[United States]] to lecture on the art of storytelling emphasising the importance of storytelling as a natural way to introduce literature to children.
==Professional storytellers in various cultures== *[[Ashik]]/ashough, in Turkic cultures *[[Bard]] *[[Pingshu]], Chinese culture *[[Dastangoi]], India *[[Fili]], Ireland *[[Goliard]] *[[Griot]], West Africa *[[Gusans]], of [[Parthia]] and [[Armenia]] of old times *[[Kobzar]], Ukraine *[[Minstrel]] *[[Dengbêj]], Kurdish epic singer *{{Interlanguage link multi|Ozan (singer)|ru|3=Озан}}, term predating ''âşık''("ashik") in Turkic cultures *[[Seanchaí]], Ireland *[[Üliger]]shin, Mongols, Buryats
==Oral storytelling festivals== {{See also|Storytelling festival}} In the 20th century oral storytelling has undergone a revival of interest and focus. Including the establishment of a number of storytelling festivals beginning with the [[National Storytelling Festival]] (USA) in [[Jonesborough, TN]].<ref>Wolf, Eric Interview with Connie Regan-Blake on the Art of Storytelling with Brother Wolf Show A history of the National Storytelling Festival. 2008</ref>
Regional storytelling festivals bring tellers of a certain state or region together for entertaining, telling and education in the art.
==Films== * ''[[How People Got Fire]]'' - Animated film about oral storytelling in Native culture
==References== {{Reflist}} * Jane Yolen; ''Favorite Folktales From Around the World.'' * Stone, Packer & Hoopes (1983); ''The Short Story-An Introduction'' * Carlson, Ann D. Storytelling. World Book Advanced. 2009
==External links== * [http://www.australianstorytelling.org.au/txt/b-whats.php Article about storytelling] * [http://www.timsheppard.co.uk/story/ Tim Sheppard's Storytelling Resources]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Oral Storytelling}} [[Category:Spoken word]] [[Category:Storytelling]] [[Category:Oral tradition|Storytelling]] [[Category:Performing arts]] [[Category:Oral literature|Storytelling]]

{{Redirect|Opéra National de Paris|the company founded in 1847 by Adolphe Adam|Opéra-National}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2012}} [[File:Paris Opera interior.jpg|thumb|The [[Palais Garnier]] opera house hall, Paris]] [[File:La salle de l'opéra Bastille vue depuis la scène.jpg|thumb|The [[Opéra Bastille]] hall, Paris]] The '''Paris Opera''' ({{Lang-fr|Opéra de Paris|link=no|italic=no}}; <small>French:</small> {{Audio-IPA|L'opera de Paris.ogg|}}) is the primary [[opera]] company of France. It was founded in 1669 by [[Louis XIV]] as the {{Lang|fr|Académie d'Opéra|italic=no}}, and shortly thereafter was placed under the leadership of [[Jean-Baptiste Lully]] and officially renamed the '''{{Lang|fr|Académie Royale de Musique|italic=no}}''', but continued to be known more simply as the {{Lang|fr|Opéra|italic=no}}. [[Classical ballet]] as it is known today arose within the Paris Opera as the [[Paris Opera Ballet]] and has remained an integral and important part of the company. Currently called the '''{{Lang|fr|Opéra National de Paris|italic=no}}''', it mainly produces operas at its modern 2700-seat theatre [[Opéra Bastille]] which opened in 1989, and [[ballet]]s and some classical operas at the older 1970-seat [[Palais Garnier]] which opened in 1875. Small scale and contemporary works are also staged in the 500-seat Amphitheatre under the Opéra Bastille.
The company's annual budget is in the order of 200 million euros, of which 100 million come from the French state and 70 million from box office receipts.<ref>[http://www.artistikrezo.com/musique/decouverte-portrait/interview-bernard-stirn-president-du-conseil-dadministration-de-lopera-de-paris.html "Bernard Stirn – Président du Conseil d'Administration de l'Opéra de Paris"], interview by Édouard Brane with the President of the Board of the Opéra, {{ill|Bernard Stirn|fr}}, 8 April 2011 {{fr icon}}</ref> With this money, the company runs the two houses and supports a large permanent staff, which includes the [[orchestra]] of 170, a [[choir|chorus]] of 110 and the ''[[corps de ballet]]'' of 150.<ref name=tola>Company profile, [http://www.tous-a-lopera.fr/2011/contenu/dp.pdf Tous à l'Opéra 2012 press release] pp. 52, 53 {{fr icon}}</ref>
Each year, the Opéra presents about 380 performances of opera, ballet and other concerts, to a total audience of about 800,000 people (of whom 17% come from abroad), which is a very good average seat occupancy rate of 94%.<ref name=tola /> In the 2012/13 season, the Opéra presented 18 opera titles (two in a double bill), 13 ballets, 5 symphonic concerts and two vocal recitals, plus 15 other programmes. The company's training bodies are also active, with 7 concerts from the Atelier Lyrique and 4 programmes from the École de Danse.<ref>Opéra national de Paris website, [http://www.operadeparis.fr/saison_2012_2013 2012/13 season presentation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120808063839/http://www.operadeparis.fr/saison_2012_2013/ |date=8 August 2012 }} {{fr icon}}</ref>
==History== {{See also|French opera}}
===The Opera under Louis XIV=== ====Pierre Perrin====
The poet [[Pierre Perrin]] began thinking and writing about the possibility of French opera in 1655, more than a decade before the official founding of the Paris Opera as an institution. He believed that the prevailing opinion of the time that the French language was fundamentally unmusical was completely incorrect. Seventeenth-century France offered Perrin essentially two types of organization for realizing his vision: a royal [[French art salons and academies|academy]] or a public theater. In 1666 he proposed to the minister [[Jean-Baptiste Colbert|Colbert]] that "the king decree 'the establishment of an Academy of Poetry and Music' whose goal would be to synthesize the French language and French music into an entirely new lyric form."<ref>Johnson (2005) p. 15.</ref>
Even though Perrin's original concept was of an academy devoted to discussions of French opera, the king's intention was in fact a unique hybrid of royal academy and public theatre, with an emphasis on the latter as an institution for performance.<ref>Johnson (2005) p. 22.</ref> On 28 June 1669, [[Louis XIV]] signed the ''Privilège accordé au Sieur Perrin pour l'établissement d'une Académie d'Opéra en musique, & Vers François'' (Privilege granted to Sir Perrin for the establishment of an Academy of Opera in music, & French Verse). The wording of the ''[[letters patent|privilège]]'', based in part on Perrin's own writings, gave him the exclusive right for 12 years to found anywhere in France academies of opera dedicated to the performance of opera in French. He was free to select business partners of his choice and to set the price of tickets. No one was to have the right of free entry including members of the royal court, and no one else could set up a similar institution.<ref>Johnson (2005) pp. 98–99.</ref> Although it was to be a public theatre, it retained its status as royal academy in which the authority of the king as the primary stakeholder was decisive. The monopoly, originally intended to protect the enterprise from competition during its formative phase, was renewed for subsequent recipients of the privilege up to the early [[French Revolution]]. As Victoria Johnson points out, "the Opera was an organization ''by nature'' so luxurious and expensive in its productions that its very survival depended on financial protection and privilege."<ref>Johnson (2005) p. 23.</ref>
Perrin converted the [[Bouteille tennis court]], located on the Rue des Fossés de Nesles (now 42 Rue Mazarine),<ref>Gourret (1985) p. 17.</ref> into a rectangular facility with provisions for stage machinery and scenery changes and a capacity of about 1200 spectators. His first opera ''[[Pomone (opera)|Pomone]]'' with music by [[Robert Cambert]] opened on 3 March 1671 and ran for 146 performances. A second work, ''Les peines et les plaisirs de l'amour'', with a libretto by [[Gabriel Gilbert]] and music by Cambert, was performed in 1672.<ref name=Harris856>Harris-Warrick, Rebecca. "Paris. 2. 1669–1725" in Sadie (1992) '''3''': 856.</ref>
====Jean-Baptiste Lully====
[[File:Jeu de Paume de Béquet (Bel-Air) - View - VJohnson 2008 p101.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|View of the [[Salle du Bel-Air]]]] Despite this early success, Cambert and two other associates did not hesitate to swindle Perrin, who was imprisoned for debt and forced to concede his privilege on 13 March 1672 to the ''surintendant'' of the king's music [[Jean-Baptiste Lully]]. The institution was renamed the Académie Royale de Musique and came to be known in France simply as the Opéra. Within one month Lully had convinced the king to expand the privilege by restricting the French and Italian comedians to using two singers rather than six, and six instrumentalists, rather than twelve. Because of legal difficulties Lully could not use the Salle de la Bouteille, and a new theatre was built by [[Carlo Vigarani]] at the [[Salle du Bel-Air|Bel-Air tennis court]] on the [[Rue de Vaugirard]].<ref name=Harris856 /> Later, Lully and his successors bitterly negotiated the concession of the privilege, in whole or in part, from the entrepreneurs in the provinces: in 1684 Pierre Gautier bought the authorisation to open a music academy in [[Marseille]], then the towns of [[Lyon]], [[Rouen]], [[Lille]] and [[Bordeaux]] followed suit in the following years.
During Lully's tenure, the only works performed were his own. The first productions were the pastorale ''Les fêtes de l'Amour et de Bacchus'' (November 1672) and his first ''tragedie lyrique'' called ''[[Cadmus et Hermione]]'' (27 April 1673).<ref name=Harris856 />
[[File:Théâtre du Palais-Royal 1673 - plan - WD Howarth 1997 p149.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.5|Vigarani's plan of the Salle du Palais-Royal]] After [[Molière]]'s death in 1673, [[Molière's company|his troupe]] merged with the players at the [[Théâtre du Marais]] to form the Théâtre Guénégaud (at the same theatre that had been used by the Académie d'Opéra), and no longer needed the theatre built by [[Cardinal Richelieu|Richelieu]] at his residence the [[Palais-Royal]], near the [[Louvre]]. (In 1680 the troupe at the Guénégaud merged again with the players from the [[Hôtel de Bourgogne (theatre)|Hôtel de Bourgogne]] forming the [[Comédie-Française]].)<ref name=Anthony>Anthony, James R. (2001). "Paris. III. 1600–1723" in Sadie (2001).</ref> Richelieu's theatre had been designed by [[Jacques Le Mercier]] and had opened in 1641, and unlike the huge [[Théâtre des Tuileries|theatre at the Tuileries Palace]], which could accommodate 6,000 to 8,000 spectators, was of a size consistent with good acoustics. Lully greatly desired a better theatre and persuaded the king to let him use the one at the Palais-Royal free of charge. The [[Théâtre du Palais-Royal (rue Saint-Honoré)|Théâtre du Palais-Royal]] had been altered in 1660 and 1671, but Lully, with 3,000 ''[[livres]]'' received from the king, had further changes made by Vigarani in 1674.<ref name=Anthony />
The first production in the new theatre was ''[[Alceste (Lully)|Alceste]]'' on 19 January 1674. The opera was bitterly attacked by those enraged at the restrictions that Lully had caused to be placed on the French and Italian comedians. To mitigate the damage, Louis XIV arranged for new works to be premiered at the court, usually at the Chateau Vieux of the [[Château de Saint-Germain-en-Laye]]. This had the further advantage of subsidizing the cost of rehearsals, as well as most of the machinery, sets, and costumes, which were donated to the Opéra for use in Paris.<ref name=LaGorce>[[Jérôme de La Gorce|La Gorce, Jérôme de]] (2001). "Lully. (1) Jean-Baptiste Lully. 1. Life" in Sadie (2001).</ref> During Lully's time at the Opéra, performances were given all year, except for three weeks at [[Easter]]. Regular performances were on Tuesdays, Fridays, and Sundays. The premieres presented at court were usually during [[Carnival]] and were moved to the Palais-Royal after Easter, where the openings were on Thursdays. About two to three new works were mounted each year. In all, thirteen of Lully's ''tragédie en musique'' were performed there (see the [[list of compositions by Jean-Baptiste Lully]]).<ref name="Harris856-7">Harris-Warrick, Rebecca (1992). "Paris. 2. 1669–1725" in Sadie (1992) '''3''': 856–857.</ref>
[[File:Plan général du Palais-Royal 1679 (Opera in blue) - Gourret 1985 p42.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Plan of the Palais-Royal in 1679 showing the location of the Paris Opera's theatre (in blue)]]
====After Lully====
After Lully died (in 1687), the number of new works per year almost doubled, since his successors ([[Pascal Collasse]], [[Henri Desmarets]], [[André Campra]], [[André Cardinal Destouches]], and [[Marin Marais]]) had greater difficulty sustaining the interest of the public. Revivals of Lully's works were common. French composers at the Opéra generally wrote music to new librettos, which had to be approved by the directors of the company. The Italian practice of preparing new settings of existing librettos was considered controversial and did not become the norm in Paris until around 1760. One of the most important of the new works during this period was an ''opéra-ballet'' by Campra called ''[[L'Europe galante]]'' presented in 1697.<ref name="Harris856-7" />
====Ballet====
In 1661 Louis XIV, who was a dancer himself and one of the great architects of [[baroque dance|baroque ballet]] (the art form which would one day evolve into [[classical ballet]]), established the [[Académie Royale de Danse]], intended to codify court and character dances and to certify dance teachers by examination.<ref name=Craine>"Académie Royale de Dance, L'" in Craine and Mackrell (2000), p. 1.</ref> From 1680 until Lully's death, it was under the direction of the great dancing master [[Pierre Beauchamp]], the man who codified the [[five positions of the feet]].<ref>Costonis (1992); Astier (1998b).</ref> When Lully took over the Opéra in 1672, he and Beauchamp made theatrical ballet an important part of the company's productions. The [[History of ballet#17th century – France and Court Dance|ballet of that time]] was merely an extension of the opera, having yet to evolve into an independent form of theatrical art. As it became more important, however, the dance component of the company began to be referred to as the [[Paris Opera Ballet]]. In 1713 an associated ballet school was opened, today known as the Paris Opera Ballet School.<ref>"Paris Opera Ballet" in Craine and Mackrell (2000), pp. 360–361; Christout (1998), pp. 87–88.</ref> The Académie Royale de Danse remained separate, and with the fall of the monarchy in 1789 it disappeared.<ref>Astier (1998a).</ref>
===The company's names after the Revolution=== [[File:Paris Opera - Theatre de l'Opera 1794-1820.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|Principal venue of the Paris Opera from 1794–1820: [[Théâtre National de la rue de la Loi|Théâtre des Arts]]|left]] With the [[French Revolution]] and the founding of the [[French First Republic|Republic]], the company changed names several times, dropping its association with the royal family (see the [[#List of official company names|List of official company names]] for details), and in 1794, moved into the [[Théâtre National de la rue de la Loi]] (capacity 2800)<ref name=Charlton867>Charlton, David (1992). "Paris. 4. 1789–1870." in Sadie (1992) '''3''': 866–867.</ref> where it took the name Théâtre des Arts.<ref name=Pitou38>Pitou (1983) '''1''': 38.</ref> In 1797, it was renamed the Théâtre de la République et des Arts.<ref name=Pitou38 />
[[Napoleon]] took control of the company in 1802 and with the declaration of the [[First French Empire|French Empire]] in 1804, renamed the company the Académie Impériale de Musique.<ref>"Book Reviews: ''Napoléon et l'Opéra: La politique sur la scéne, 1810–1815'' by David Chaillou." ''The English Historical Review'' '''122''' (496): 486–490 (2007). {{doi|10.1093/ehr/cem021}}.</ref> With the [[Bourbon Restoration|Restoration]] in 1814, the company was renamed the Académie Royale de Musique. It became part of the [[Académie des Beaux-Arts]] in 1816. In 1821, the company moved to the [[Salle Le Peletier]], which had a capacity of 1900 spectators and where it remained until the building was destroyed by fire in 1873.
In the second half of the 19th century, with the ascension of [[Napoleon III]] in 1851, the name Académie Impériale de Musique was reinstated and after 1870 with the formation of the [[French Third Republic|Third Republic]], was changed to Théâtre National de l'Opéra.<ref name=Charlton867 /> In 1875, the institution occupied a new home, the [[Palais Garnier]].<ref name=LanghamSmith874>Langham Smith, Richard (1992). "Paris. 5. 1870–1902." in Sadie (1992) '''3''': 874.</ref> Between 1908 and 1914 [[Henri Benjamin Rabaud]] conducted at Palais Garnier. Rabaud also composed several works which first premiered at [[Opéra-Comique]], but were later also performed at Palais Garnier.<ref name=pitou>{{Cite book| publisher = Greenwood Press| isbn = 978-0-313-27783-2| last = Pitou| first = Spire| title = The Paris Opera: An Encyclopedia of Operas, Ballets, Composers, and Performers; Growth and Grandeur, 1815-1914; M-Z| date = 1990}}</ref>
In 1939, the Opéra was merged with the [[Opéra-Comique]] and the company name became Réunion des Théâtres Lyriques Nationaux. The Opéra-Comique was closed in 1972 with the appointment of [[Rolf Liebermann]] as general administrator of the Théâtre National de l'Opéra de Paris (1973–1980), but in 1976, the Opéra-Comique was restored.
In 1990 the Opéra moved its primary venue to the new [[Opéra-Bastille]], becoming the Opéra de Paris, although it continued to mount productions, primarily ballet, at the Palais Garnier; and the Opéra-Comique regained its autonomy. In 1994 the Opéra de Paris became the Opéra National de Paris.<ref name=ParisOperaWebsite>[http://www.operadeparis.fr/cns11/live/onp/L_Opera/L_Opera_de_Paris/histoire_de_l_Opera.php?lang=en "Opéra national de Paris – Histoire de l’Opéra national de Paris"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718030541/http://www.operadeparis.fr/cns11/live/onp/L_Opera/L_Opera_de_Paris/histoire_de_l_Opera.php?lang=en |date=18 July 2011 }} at the official website {{fr icon}}. Retrieved 25 March 2010.</ref> Regardless of all the changes in its "official" name, the company and its theatres were commonly referred to as the Opéra.

Consistent with this date, Guest 2008, p. 326, mentions that in 1840 Pillet, "as Director of the Opera", sent an emissary to London to negotiate a reappearance of the ballerina [[Marie Taglioni]] at the Paris Opera.</ref> | Henri Duponchel, Édouard Monnais, [[Léon Pillet]] |- | align="right" valign="top"| 1 June 1841<ref>Fontaine 2003, p. 23, says Duponchel and Pillet became co-directors on 1 June 1841 (without Monnais). == See also == {{Portal|Opera|Ballet|Paris}}
=== Other Parisian opera companies and theatres === In the period from 1725 to 1791 there were essentially four public theatres which were permitted in Paris:<ref name=Harris3 /> *Opéra de Paris *[[Comédie-Française]] *[[Comédie-Italienne]] *[[Opéra-Comique]] In 1762, the Opéra-Comique merged with the Comédie-Italienne.
In 1791, the laws were changed allowing almost anyone to open a public theatre. This led to rapid growth in the number of theatres and companies and complexities in their naming. Theatres might burn down and be rebuilt using the name of an old or new company or patron. Some of the new theatres that appeared during this period include:<ref>Charlton, David; Johnson, Janet. "Paris. 4. 1789–1870." in Sadie (1992) '''3''': 870–873.</ref> {{Div col|colwidth=30em|rules=yes}} *[[Théâtre Feydeau]] *[[Comédie-Italienne|Théâtre Italien]] *[[Théâtre Lyrique]] *[[Théâtre de l'Ambigu-Comique]] *[[Théâtre des Bouffes-Parisiens]] *[[Amphithéâtre Anglais|Cirque Olympique]] *[[Théâtre de la Gaîté (boulevard du Temple)|Théâtre de la Gaîté]] *[[Théâtre du Gymnase Marie Bell|Gymnase-Dramatique]] *[[Théâtre des Nouveautés]] *[[Odéon Theatre|Théâtre de l'Odeon]] *[[Théâtre de la Porte Saint-Martin|Porte-St-Martin]] *[[Théâtre de la Renaissance]] *[[Théâtre des Variétés]] *[[Théâtre du Vaudeville]] {{Div col end}} After about 1870, the situation was simpler with regard to opera, with primarily the Opéra and the Opéra-Comique in operation. The naming situation became somewhat confusing after the Opéra-Comique's theater (the second Salle Favart) burned on 25 May 1887, since the company began performing in other locations. Companies other than the Opéra producing operas or operettas at various theatres in this period included:<ref>Charlton, David; Johnson, Janet. "Paris. 4. 1789–1870." in Sadie (1992) '''3''': 873–874.</ref> {{Div col|colwidth=30em|rules=yes}} *[[Opéra-Comique]] at Salle Favart (2), [[Théâtre de la Ville|Théâtre Lyrique]], [[Théâtre du Château-d'Eau]], Salle Favart (3) *[[Opéra National Lyrique]] at [[Théâtre de la Gaîté (rue Papin)|Théâtre de la Gaîté]] *[[Eden-Théâtre]] (''[[Lohengrin (opera)|Lohengrin]]'', 1887) *[[Opéra Populaire]] performing at [[Théâtre du Châtelet]], Théâtre de la Gaîté, and Théâtre du Château-d'Eau *Théâtre du Château-d'Eau *Théâtre Lyrique performing at [[Salle de l'Athénée]], Théâtre du Château-d'Eau, and [[Théâtre de la Renaissance]] *Nouveau-Lyrique at [[Théâtre Taitbout]] *[[Théâtre de l'Odéon]] (plays with incidental music by, e.g. Bizet, Fauré) *[[Théâtre de la Ville]] *[[Théâtre du Châtelet]] *[[Théâtre des Champs-Élysées]] {{Div col end}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Use British English|date=September 2015}} {{refimprove|date=June 2013}} [[File:Menier Chocolate Factory.jpg|thumb|Menier Chocolate Factory]] '''Southwark Street''' is a major street in [[Bankside]] in the [[London Borough of Southwark]], in [[London]] England, just south of the [[River Thames]].<ref>[http://www.londontown.com/LondonStreets/southwark_street_553.html London guide to Southwark Street, SE1], LondonTown.com.</ref> It runs between [[Blackfriars Road]] to the west and [[Borough High Street]] to the east. It also connects the access routes for [[London Bridge]], [[Southwark Bridge]] and [[Blackfriars Bridge]]. At the eastern end to the north is [[Borough Market]].
The road forms part of the A3200, which continues with [[Stamford Street]] to the west.
== History ==
In April 1856, the [[St Saviour's District (Metropolis)|St Saviour's District Board]] petitioned the [[Metropolitan Board of Works]] to create a new street to run between the [[South Eastern Railway (UK)|South Eastern Railway]] terminus at [[London Bridge station]] and the [[West End of London|West End]].<ref>Sir Howard Roberts and Walter H. Godfrey (editors), [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=65327 Southwark Street], ''Survey of London: volume 22: Bankside (the parishes of St. Saviour and Christchurch Southwark)'', chapter 15, page 90, 1950.</ref> The street was the first to be made by the Board and was completed in 1864. It was driven across a densely occupied part of the parish and crosses older roads and streets which created oddly shaped plots for redevelopment. Its junction with Borough High Street is so gently curved that the transition between the streets leads to confusion and imprecision as to which is which and the street numbering and lack of a street name plate compounds this, the break between them occurs at the junction with Bedale Street on the north-side but at the south-side the street does not begin until after the 'fork' opposite Stoney Street, some 130 metres to the west. Under the street, a tunnel was constructed with side passages to carry utilities such as gas, water, and drainage pipes, together with [[telegraph]] wires for communication. This was an advanced feature for the time.
[[File:South facade of Borough market on Southwark Street - geograph.org.uk - 1522143.jpg|thumb|South facade of Borough Market on Southwark Street]] During the first decade of the street's existence, many large commercial buildings were built along the street. The Hop Exchange, of 1874, is the most notable building at the northern side filling most of the quadrant formed by the street and the railway viaduct. Built in the 1870s, the former [[Menier Chocolate Factory]] factory on Southwark Street was converted to an arts complex that incorporates an [[art gallery]], [[restaurant]], and [[theatre]], opening in 2004.<ref>[http://www.menierchocolatefactory.com/ Menier Chocolate Factory].</ref> In 1932 Borough Market built a formal gateway with administrative offices at Nos 6 and 8. In 1958 the Trustees erected a small office building at the junction with Stoney Street 'St Margaret's House'. At No 110, the western-end of the street, is the headquarters of IPC Media at the 'Blue Fin Building' completed in 2007.
Under the railway bridge carrying trains to Blackfriars Station from the south some urban art work has been placed on the south-side, whilst on the north-side the word 'Bankside' has been placed in very large lettering occupying most of the wall against the pavement. This is part of the area and tourist branding as the relationship with the ancient district of [[Bankside]] is tenuous, the most that can be said is that Southwark Street defines the southernmost limit of Bankside.
The building on the south-west corner of the junction with Great Guildford Street is, unusually, numbered 59½.
[[Ian Davenport]]s' 2006 painting ''[[Poured Lines]]'' is displayed under the rail bridge at the western end of Southwark Street. It is the largest painting to be publicly displayed outdoors in the United Kingdom.<ref name=BBC06>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/5315186.stm|title=The big picture|date=5 September 2006|work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.urban75.org/vista/southwark.html Under the railway bridge at Southwark Street, near London Bridge] — photographic 360° interactive panorama.
{{Metropolitan Board of Works}} {{coord|51|30|20|N|0|06|01|W|region:GB_scale:10000|display=title}} {{commons category|Southwark Street}}

{{Italic title}} '''''Ten Stories About Smoking''''' is the debut short story collection by writer [[Stuart Evers]].<ref name=newstates>{{cite web|last=Preston|first=Alex|title=Ten Stories About Smoking|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/books/2011/02/stories-smoking-evers-short|publisher=New Statesman|accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref><ref name=telegraph>{{cite news|last=Walton|first=James|title=A Page in the Life: Stuart Evers|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/bookreviews/8373442/A-Page-in-the-Life-Stuart-Evers.html|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=25 April 2012|location=London|date=10 March 2011}}</ref><ref name=guardian>{{cite news|last=Segal|first=Francesca|title=Ten Stories About Smoking by Stuart Evers|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2011/apr/02/stuart-evers-ten-stories-smoking-review|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=25 April 2012|location=London|date=2 April 2011}}</ref><ref name=picador>{{cite web|title=Stuart Evers|url=http://www.picador.com/authors/Stuart-Evers|publisher=Picador|accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref><ref name=edinburgh>{{cite web|title=Stuart Evers|url=http://www.edbookfest.co.uk/writers/stuart-evers|publisher=Edinburgh International Book Festival|accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{Notability|date=November 2018}} {{More citations needed|date=November 2018}} }} '''''The Art Gorgeous''''' is a contemporary art magazine founded in 2015<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theartgorgeous.com/about-2/|title=About Luxury Artist Creative Collaborations - The Art Gorgeous|last=|first=|date=|website=The Art Gorgeous|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-04}}</ref> by CEO and founding editor Cordelia Noe.<ref name="blouinartinfo">{{Cite news|url=https://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/1905614/the-resident-cordelia-and-christoph-noes-hong-kong|title=The Resident: Cordelia and Christoph Noe’s Hong Kong {{!}} Artinfo|work=[[Blouinartinfo]]|access-date=2018-11-04|language=en}}</ref> Initially founded in Hong Kong, the bi-annual [[Publication|print publication]] and daily [[blog]] focuses on the cross-section between [[fashion]], luxury and the [[art world]].<ref name="blouinartinfo"/> It is based in Milan, Italy.
== History == The magazine was founded in 2015 by Noe. The name of the magazine comes from seeing a stylish woman at an art world event, like an art fair, and noticing her "tasteful, stylish and sharp appearance," which is defined as 'the art gorgeous'.
The first interview was a Q&A with art historian Angelica Taschen on her personal style. Since then, over 100 artists<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theartgorgeous.com/about-2/|title=About Luxury Artist Creative Collaborations - The Art Gorgeous|website=The Art Gorgeous|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-04}}</ref> have been interviewed for the magazine.
== Style == The magazine also features art news, art reviews,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.annkakultys.com/tag/the-art-gorgeous/|title=the art gorgeous – ANNKA KULTYS GALLERY|website=www.annkakultys.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref> celebrity news, brand collaborations and interviews with inspiring women working in the art world, artists, and art advisors, art patrons, curators and art collectors. They have featured interviews with women entrepreneurs like art advisor [[Chrissy Crafword]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.artstar.com/blogs/news/the-art-gorgeous-features-chrissy-crawford|title=The Art Gorgeous Features Chrissy Crawford|work=ArtStar|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref> Hong Kong gallerist Pearl Lam<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://jingdaily.com/interview-pearl-lam-of-pearl-lam-galleries/|title=Interview: Pearl Lam of Pearl Lam Galleries {{!}} Jing Daily|date=2015-12-14|work=Jing Daily|access-date=2018-11-22|language=en-US}}</ref> and artist Tauba Auerbach.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/tauba-auerbach-vienna-state-opera-curtain-405968|title=Tauba Auerbach Designs Vienna Opera Curtain - artnet News|date=2016-01-13|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-11-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
The magazine has a non-academic approach to covering contemporary art. It covers industry news, art week travel guides and art fair style and art coverage. They have created magazine issues with collaborations with artists like [[Kaws]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/theartgorgeous/docs/magazine_issue_4_low-res_|title=TheArtGorgeous - Issue 4 Spring/Summer 2018|work=Issuu|access-date=2018-11-22|language=en}}</ref> and brands like [[Gucci]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@artgorgeous/gucci-goes-woof-at-the-art-gorgeous-2e49392ac57b|title=Gucci Goes Woof at The Art Gorgeous|last=Gorgeous|first=The Art|date=2018-06-04|website=The Art Gorgeous|access-date=2018-11-22}}</ref>
The magazine also rus the Art X Lux conference, which is an industry gathering between fashion brands and the art world<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://jingdaily.com/event-watch-art-x-lux-conference-business-creative-collaborations/|title=Event Watch {{!}} Art x Lux Conference: The Business of Creative Collaborations {{!}} Jing Daily|date=2016-08-04|work=Jing Daily|access-date=2018-11-22|language=en-US}}</ref> and leaders in luxury marketing.
== References == <references />
== External links == *{{Official website|theartgorgeous.com}}
[[Category:Art magazines|Art Gorgeous]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox film |name = The Help |image = Help poster.jpg |alt = Two black maids standing, beside two white women on a bench. Against a bright yellow background, the text in light purple. |caption = Theatrical release poster |director = [[Tate Taylor]] |producer = {{Plain list| *[[Chris Columbus (filmmaker)|Chris Columbus]] *[[Michael Barnathan]] *[[Brunson Green]] }} |writer = Tate Taylor |based on = {{Based on|''[[The Help]]''|[[Kathryn Stockett]]}} |starring = {{Plain list| *[[Viola Davis]] *[[Octavia Spencer]] *[[Emma Stone]] *[[Jessica Chastain]] *[[Bryce Dallas Howard]] *[[Allison Janney]] }} |music = [[Thomas Newman]] |cinematography = [[Stephen Goldblatt]] |editing = [[Hughes Winborne]] |studio = [[DreamWorks|DreamWorks Pictures]]
[[Reliance Entertainment]]
[[Participant Media]]
[[Image Nation]]
[[1492 Pictures]]
[[Brunson Green|Harbinger Pictures]] |distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Walt Disney Studios
Motion Pictures]] |released = {{film date|2011|08|09|[[Beverly Hills]]|2011|8|10|United States}} |runtime = 146 minutes |country = United States |language = English |budget = $25 million{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=help2011.htm|title=The Help|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=June 26, 2018}} |gross = $216.6 million }} '''''The Help''''' is a 2011 American [[Historical period drama|period drama film]] written and directed by [[Tate Taylor]] and [[film adaptation|adapted]] from [[Kathryn Stockett]]'s 2009 [[The Help|novel of the same name]]. The film features an [[ensemble cast]], including [[Jessica Chastain]], [[Viola Davis]], [[Bryce Dallas Howard]], [[Allison Janney]], [[Octavia Spencer]] and [[Emma Stone]]. The film and novel recount the story of young white woman and aspiring [[journalist]] Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan.{{cite web |title=Viola Davis on making 'The Help' work |url=https://www.newsday.com/entertainment/movies/viola-davis-on-making-the-help-work-1.3075367 |publisher=JOHN ANDERSON}} The story focuses on her relationship with two black maids, Aibileen Clark and Minny Jackson, during the [[Civil Rights Movement]] in 1963 [[Jackson, Mississippi]]. In an attempt to become a legitimate journalist and writer, Skeeter decides to write a book from the point of view of the maids—referred to as "the help"— exposing the [[racism]] they are faced with as they work for white families. [[DreamWorks|DreamWorks Pictures]] acquired the [[Film rights|screen rights]] to Stockett's novel in March 2010 and quickly commissioned the film into production with [[Chris Columbus (filmmaker)|Chris Columbus]], [[Michael Barnathan]], and [[Brunson Green]] as producers. The film's casting began later that month, with [[principal photography]] following four months after in [[Mississippi]]. [[Touchstone Pictures]] released ''The Help'' worldwide, with a [[Wide release|general theatrical release]] in North America on August 10, 2011. The film was a critical and commercial success, receiving positive reviews and grossing $216 million in worldwide box office. ''The Help'' received four [[Academy Award]] nominations including [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]], [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] for Davis, and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] for both Chastain and Spencer, with the latter winning the award. The film also won the [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture]]. ==Plot== In 1963, Aibileen Clark is an African-American maid in [[Jackson, Mississippi]], and in intermittent voice overs she tells her "career" story to the aspiring writer Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan, a recent graduate of [[University of Mississippi|Ole Miss]] and a friend of Aibileen's employer and fellow socialite Elizabeth Leefolt. Aibileen cares for the Leefolt's daughter, Mae Mobley, whom Elizabeth neglects. Aibileen's best friend is the plain-spoken Minny Jackson, who works for Mrs. Walters, the mother of Hilly Holbrook, the leader of the women's socialite group. Skeeter is uncomfortable with the racist attitudes of her socialite friends towards their maids. She is shocked when Hilly forwards a letter to the Home Sanitation Initiative to install separate bathrooms for the help. Skeeter later learns that her mother Charlotte fired her childhood maid Constantine for unknown reasons. During a terrible storm, Minny refuses to go out to use the help's toilet and uses the guest's bathroom, resulting in her getting fired by Hilly, who then slanders her name with claims of theft, rendering her essentially unemployable. Minny eventually finds a job with Celia, wife of Johnny Foote, Hilly's former beau. The two become friends through Minny's cooking lessons, though they keep Minny's employment secret from Johnny. Celia suffers a miscarriage and reveals to Minny that she has suffered three previous miscarriages. Minny comes upon Skeeter's visiting Aibileen and joins in the book project effort. Skeeter is advised by her book editor at Harper & Row, Elaine Stein, that the stories of two maids are not enough, but potential retribution from the maid's employers hinders others from joining the project. Aibileen tells Skeeter about the pain she experiences about her son being fatally crushed while on the job. Aibileen has struggled to find closure from his death, and believes that helping with the book will enable her to find that closure. Hilly refuses to lend more money to her replacement maid, Yule May, who is struggling to send her twin sons to college. One day, she discovers a discarded ring and pawns it. However, Yule May is brutally arrested after Hilly reports the theft. Following this and the assassination of [[Medgar Evers]], more maids come forward with their stories, believing the book would help put an end to the brutality against African-Americans. Following the [[assassination of John F. Kennedy]], Skeeter, Aibileen, and Minny fear that the maids' stories will be recognized. Minny then reveals the "terrible awful" that she did to Hilly: following her termination, Minny baked her renowned chocolate pie and gave it to Hilly. Minny, however, prevented Mrs. Walters from having a slice, and revealed that she baked her own excrement into the pie. Its inclusion in the book would prompt Hilly to crusade in denial that the book is about Jackson. Skeeter confronts her mother Charlotte about Constantine's termination. Charlotte reveals that during a lunch with the local chapter of the [[Daughters of America]], Constantine's daughter Rachel arrived. Rachel disobeyed Charlotte's orders of entering through the kitchen and embarrassed her. In order to save face, Charlotte fired Constantine and ordered them both to leave. Shortly afterward, Rachel took Constantine to Chicago, where she later died. Charlotte had every intention to bring Constantine back to Jackson. The book is published anonymously, and it is a success. Minny reveals the "terrible awful" to Celia, who finally sees Hilly as the manipulative bully that she is. Celia lets on that she knows about the "terrible awful" by writing a check to one of Hilly's charity groups made out to "Two Slice Hilly". Incensed, Hilly confronts and attempts to intimidate Skeeter through threat of legal proceedings, but she reminds Hilly that "that" is in chapter 12. Charlotte then intervenes, lets on that she knows about the "terrible awful" and orders Hilly off the property. Charlotte and Skeeter reconcile when Charlotte tells her how proud she is about her courage, the book and the job offer in New York City. Johnny approaches Minny and reveals that he knew that she'd been working at his house, how appreciative he is about her friendship with Celia, how it saved her life, and that she has permanent job security. This act of kindness gives Minny the courage to take her children away from her abusive husband and never look back. In an attempt to seek revenge for helping Skeeter, Hilly pressures Elizabeth to terminate Aibileen, with Hilly present and trying to frame Aibileen for theft. But Aibileen stands up to Hilly, calling her a godless woman, never satisfied until she gets what she wants. Elizabeth orders Aibileen to leave. Aibileen bids farewell to Elizabeth's daughter and pleads with Elizabeth to give her daughter a chance, as Elizabeth begins to cry. Aibileen reflects on the ordeal and finds closure. She looks to her future as a writer. ==Cast== [[File:The Help cast.jpg|thumb|''The Help'' cast at [[18th Screen Actors Guild Awards]] ([[Octavia Spencer]] in center, holding the cast's award)]] {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Viola Davis]] as Aibileen Clark *[[Emma Stone]] as Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan *[[Octavia Spencer]] as Minny Jackson *[[Bryce Dallas Howard]] as Hilly Walters Holbrook *[[Jessica Chastain]] as Celia Rae Foote *[[Allison Janney]] as Charlotte Phelan *[[Ahna O'Reilly]] as Elizabeth Leefolt *[[Sissy Spacek]] as Mrs. Walters *[[Chris Lowell]] as Stuart Whitworth *[[Mike Vogel]] as Johnny Foote *[[Cicely Tyson]] as Constantine Bates *[[Anna Camp]] as Jolene French *[[Brian Kerwin]] as Robert Phelan *[[Aunjanue Ellis]] as Yule May Davis *Ted Welch as William Holbrook *[[Wes Chatham]] as Carlton Phelan *[[Shane McRae]] as Raleigh Leefolt *Roslyn Ruff as Pascagoula *Tarra Riggs as Gretchen *[[LaChanze]] as Rachel Bates *[[Mary Steenburgen]] as Elaine Stein *[[Leslie Jordan]] as Mr. Blackly *[[David Oyelowo]] as Preacher Green *[[Dana Ivey]] as Grace Higginbotham *Tiffany Brouwer as Rebecca *Carol Lee as Pearly *Carol Sutton as Cora *Millicent Bolton as Callie *[[Ashley Johnson]] as Mary Beth Caldwell *[[Nelsan Ellis]] as Henry {{div col end}} ==Production== In December 2009, Variety reported that Chris Columbus, Michael Barnathan, and Mark Radcliffe would produce a film adaptation of The Help, under their production company [[1492 Pictures]]. [[Brunson Green]] of Harbinger Productions also co-produced. The film was written and directed by Stockett's childhood friend, Tate Taylor, who optioned film rights to the book before its publication.{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Fleming|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118012807.html?categoryid=1238&cs=1|title=Chris Columbus Fast-Tracks 'Help' – His 1492 Prods. Readies Adaptation of Stockett Novel|date=December 15, 2009|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|accessdate=July 7, 2012}} [[DreamWorks]] acquired the film rights to the novel in March 2010.{{cite news|last1=Fernandez|first1=Jay A.|title=DreamWorks nabs rights to novel 'The Help'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/dreamworks-nabs-rights-novel-help-21325|accessdate=April 26, 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=August 17, 2011}} [[Reliance Entertainment]] and [[Participant Media]] co-produced the film.{{cite news|last1=Bart|first1=Peter|last2=Patrick|first2=Frater|title=India's Reliance: Still a DreamWorks Backer, But Hollywood Sojourn Has Cost a Fortune|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/indias-reliance-continues-to-back-dreamworks-but-its-hollywood-sojourn-has-cost-a-fortune-1201179612/|accessdate=April 29, 2016|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=May 14, 2014}} The first casting news for the production came in March 2010, when it was reported that Stone was attached to play the role of Eugenia "Skeeter" Phelan.{{cite news|first=Mike|last=Sampson|url=http://www.joblo.com/movie-news/emma-stone-looks-to-dreamworks-for-help|title=Emma Stone Looks to Dreamworks for 'Help'|date=March 23, 2010|work = [[JoBlo.com]]|publisher=Joblo Media|accessdate = March 23, 2010|dead-url=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023053807/http://www.joblo.com/movie-news/emma-stone-looks-to-dreamworks-for-help|archivedate=October 23, 2012}} Other actors were since cast, including Davis as Aibileen; Howard as Hilly Holbrook, Jackson's snooty town ringleader; Janney as Charlotte Phelan, Skeeter's mother; and Lowell as Stuart Whitworth, Skeeter's boyfriend and a senator's son.{{cite news|last=Rich|first=Katey|title=Viola Davis in Talks To Join Emma Stone in the Help|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Viola-Davis-In-Talks-To-Join-Emma-Stone-In-The-Help-18112.html|work = Cinema Blend|publisher=GatewayBlend Entertainment|date=April 15, 2010|accessdate=May 26, 2010}}{{cite news|last=Fleming|first=Mike|title=Bryce Dallas Howard Lands 'The Help'|url=http://www.deadline.com/2010/04/bryce-dallas-howard-lands-the-help/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|date=April 27, 2010|accessdate=May 26, 2010}}{{cite news|last=Kit |first=Zorianna |title=Chris Lowell Eyes 'The Help' |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3i6bdd9c879228ff5186e11a822cc02ac2 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=May 20, 2010 |accessdate=May 26, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100524102608/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3i6bdd9c879228ff5186e11a822cc02ac2 |archivedate=May 24, 2010 }} [[Leslie Jordan]] appears as the editor of the fictional local newspaper, ''The Jackson Journal''.{{cite news|last=Pierce|first=Susan|title='The Help' Is Coming|url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/2010/jul/24/help-coming/|work = [[Chattanooga Times Free Press]]|date=July 24, 2010|accessdate=July 26, 2010}} [[Mike Vogel]] plays the character Johnny Foote. [[Octavia Spencer]] portrays Minny. A longtime friend of Stockett and Taylor, Spencer inspired the character of Minny in Stockett's novel and voiced her in the audiobook version.{{cite news|last=Sperling|first=Nicole|title=Octavia Spencer Nabs Key Role in 'The Help'|url=http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2010/05/17/octavia-spencer-lands-supporting-role-in-the-help/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=May 17, 2010|accessdate=May 26, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100521065804/http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2010/05/17/octavia-spencer-lands-supporting-role-in-the-help/|archivedate=May 21, 2010|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|last=Sperling|first=Nicole|title='The Help' Exclusive: Allison Janney Joins the Cast|url=http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2010/07/13/the-help-exclusive-allison-janney-joins-the-cast/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=July 13, 2010|accessdate=July 23, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725104140/http://hollywoodinsider.ew.com/2010/07/13/the-help-exclusive-allison-janney-joins-the-cast/|archivedate=July 25, 2010|df=mdy-all}} Filming began in July 2010 and extended through October. The town of [[Greenwood, Mississippi|Greenwood]], Mississippi, was chosen to portray 1960s-era Jackson, and producer Green said he had expected to shoot "95 percent" of the film there.{{cite web|title=The Help: Press Kit|url=http://www.bvifinland.fi/uploads/text/THE_HELP_Press_Kit_FINAL_7-25-11.pdf|publisher=DreamWorks II Distribution|accessdate=September 13, 2016|dead-url=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160709135149/http://www.bvifinland.fi/uploads/text/THE_HELP_Press_Kit_FINAL_7-25-11.pdf|archivedate=July 9, 2016}} Parts of the film were also shot in the real-life Jackson, as well as in nearby [[Clarksdale, Mississippi|Clarksdale]] and [[Greenville, Mississippi|Greenville]]. One of the few locations that existed in 1963 Jackson, the book and the film is Jackson landmark [http://www.brentsdrugs.com Brent's Drugs], which dates to 1946. Other locations that can still be found in Jackson include the [[Mississippi State Capitol|New Capitol Building]] and the Mayflower Cafe downtown. Scenes set at the ''Jackson Journal'' office were shot in Clarksdale at the building which formerly housed the ''[[Clarksdale Press Register]]'' for 40 years until April 2010.{{cite news|last=Moser|first=Christopher|title=Lights, Camera, Clarksdale!|url=http://www.pressregister.com/articles/2010/07/09/news/doc4c3643ced90b3142876199.txt|newspaper=[[Clarksdale Press Register]]|date=July 9, 2010|accessdate=July 23, 2010}} ''The Help'' was the most significant film production in Mississippi since ''[[O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]'' (2000){{cite news|last=Kuykendall|first=Taylor|title=Movie Adaption of Bestseller To Be Filmed Here|url=http://gwcommonwealth.com/articles/2010/05/13/news/top_stories/05132010news01.txt|work = [[The Greenwood Commonwealth]]|date=May 13, 2010|accessdate=May 26, 2010}}{{dead link|date=December 2016}}{{cite news|last=Ayres|first=Jeff|title=Movie To Have $13M Impact on Delta|url=http://www.clarionledger.com/article/20100514/NEWS/5140338/Movie+to+have++13M+impact+on+Delta|work = [[The Clarion Ledger]]|publisher=[[Gannett Company]]|date=May 14, 2010|accessdate=May 26, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite news|last=Byrd|first=Shelia|title='The Help' To Start Filming in Miss. This Summer|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hxPXbgA9hHcpzDsbV2HWtcgBoMBQD9FM6NG80|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100517061048/http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hxPXbgA9hHcpzDsbV2HWtcgBoMBQD9FM6NG80|dead-url=yes|archive-date=May 17, 2010|publisher=[[Associated Press]] |via=[[Google News]]|date=May 13, 2010|accessdate=May 26, 2010|df=mdy-all}} "Honestly, my heart would be broken if it were set anywhere but Mississippi", Stockett wrote in an e-mail to reporters. In order to convince producers to shoot in Greenwood, Tate Taylor and others had previously come to the town and scouted out locations; at his first meeting with DreamWorks executives, he presented them with a photo album of potential filming spots in the area. The state's tax incentive program for filmmakers was also a key enticement in the decision. ==Release== [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures]] distributed ''The Help'' worldwide through the studio's [[Touchstone Pictures]] banner.{{cite news|last1=McClintock|first1=Pamela|title='The Help': Why It Took a Year to Cast the Film|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/help-why-took-a-year-224589|accessdate=April 26, 2016|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=August 17, 2011}} On October 13, 2010, Disney gave the film a release date of August 12, 2011. On June 30, 2011, the film's release date was rescheduled two days earlier to August 10, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/06/30/the-help-moves-release-date-to/ |title='The Help' Moves Up Its Release Date to Aug. 10|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=June 30, 2011|accessdate=June 26, 2018|first=Anthony|last=Breznican}} ===Home media=== The film was released by [[Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment|Touchstone Home Entertainment]] on [[Blu-ray Disc]], DVD, and [[Digital distribution|digital download]] on December 6, 2011. The release was produced in three different physical packages: a three-disc combo pack (Blu-ray, DVD, and Digital Copy); a two-disc combo pack (Blu-ray and DVD); and a single-disc DVD. It was also released as a digital download option in both standard and high definition. The DVD version includes two deleted scenes and ''The Living Proof'' music video by [[Mary J. Blige]]. The digital download version includes the same features as the DVD version, plus one additional deleted scene. Both the two-disc and three-disc combo packs include the same features as the DVD version, as well as "The Making of 'The Help': From Friendship to Film", "In Their Own Words: A Tribute to the Maids of Mississippi", and three deleted scenes with introductions by director Taylor.{{cite news|title=The Help Is Coming Home on December 6|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=82933|accessdate=October 5, 2011|work = ComingSoon.net|publisher=[[CraveOnline Media]]|date=October 5, 2011|author=Coming Soon}}{{cite news|title=The Help Is Coming to Your House This December|url=http://www.moviehole.net/201146490-the-help-is-coming-to-your-house-this-december|accessdate=October 5, 2011|newspaper=Moviehole|date=October 5, 2011|author=Jessica}}{{cite news|last=Katz|first=Josh|title=The Help Blu-Ray|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/news/?id=7488|accessdate=October 5, 2011|work=Blu-ray.com|date=October 5, 2011}} ==Reception== ===Critical response=== ''The Help'' received mostly positive reviews from critics. Review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported that 75% of 216 professional critics gave the film a positive review, with an average score of 7/10. The website's critical consensus states, "Though arguably guilty of glossing over its racial themes, ''The Help'' rises on the strength of its cast—particularly [[Viola Davis]], whose performance is powerful enough to carry the film on its own."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_help/|title=The Help (2011)|publisher=[[Fandango Media]] |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|accessdate=June 25, 2018}} [[Metacritic]], a review aggregator which assigns a [[weighted average]] score out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, gives the film a score of 62 based on 41 reviews.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/the-help/|title=The Help Reviews|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=November 1, 2011}} [[CinemaScore]] polls reported that the average grade moviegoers gave the film was an "A+" on an A+ to F scale.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-update-help-earns-221677|title=Box Office Update: 'The Help' Earns a Rare A+ CinemaScore from Moviegoers|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|accessdate=November 1, 2011|first=Pamela|last=McClintock|date=August 10, 2011}} Tom Long from ''[[The Detroit News]]'' remarked about the film: "Appealling, entertaining, touching and perhaps even a bit healing, ''The Help'' is an old-fashioned grand yarn of a film, the sort we rarely get these days."{{dead link|date=July 2012}} {{cite web|url=http://www.detnews.com/article/20110810/ENT02/108100304/1034/ent02/%E2%80%9960s-story-of-racism-richly-told/|title=Movies {{!}} '60s Story of Racism Richly Told|work = [[The Detroit News]]|date=August 10, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011}} Connie Ogle of ''[[The Miami Herald]]'' gave the film three out of four stars and said it "will make you laugh, yes, but it can also break your heart. In the dog days of August moviegoing, that's a powerful recommendation."{{cite web|last=Ogle|first=Connie|url=http://www.miami.com/039the-help039-pg-13-article-0/|title='The Help' (PG-13)|work = [[The Miami Herald]]|accessdate=August 29, 2011}} A more mixed review from Karina Longworth of ''[[The Village Voice]]'' said: "We get a fairly typical Hollywood flattening of history, with powerful villains and disenfranchised heroes."{{cite web|first=Karina|last=Longworth|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2011-08-10/film/the-help-mean-girls-vs-the-maids/|title=Civil Rights Through a Soft Focus Lens in The Help|work = [[The Village Voice]]|date=August 10, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011}} Rick Groen of ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'', giving the film two out of four stars, said: "Typically, this sort of film is an earnest tear-jerker with moments of levity. Instead, what we have here is a raucous rib-tickler with occasional pauses for a little dramatic relief."{{cite news|first=Rick|last=Groen|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/arts/movies/the-help-civil-rights-lite-played-for-laughs/article2124164/|title=The Help: Civil Rights Lite, Played for Laughs|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=August 10, 2011|accessdate=August 29, 2011}} Referring to the film as a "big, ole slab of honey-glazed hokum", ''[[The New York Times]]'' noted that "save for Ms. Davis's, however, the performances are almost all overly broad, sometimes excruciatingly so, characterized by loud laughs, bugging eyes and pumping limbs."{{cite news|authorlink = Manohla Dargis|last= Dargis|first= Manohla|title='The Maids' Now Have Their Say|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2011/08/10/movies/the-help-spans-two-worlds-white-and-black-review.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=February 12, 2012|work = [[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|date=August 9, 2011}} Some of the negative reviews criticized the film for its inability to match the quality of the book. Chris Hewitt of the ''[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]'' said about the film: "Some adaptations find a fresh, cinematic way to convey a book's spirit but ''The Help'' doesn't."{{cite web|url=http://www.twincities.com/movies/ci_18649721/ |title='The Help' Review: Movie Based on Beloved Book Will Be Loved Best If You've Read the Book|work=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|publisher=Digital First Media|first=Chris|last=Hewitt|date=August 9, 2011|accessdate=June 26, 2018}} Many critics praised the performances of Davis and Spencer. Wilson Morales of Blackfilm.com gave the movie three out of four stars and commented, "With powerful performances given by Viola Davis and scene stealer Octavia Spencer, the film is an emotionally moving drama that remains highly entertaining."{{cite web|last=Morales|first=Wilson|url=http://www.blackfilm.com/read/2011/08/the-help-film-review/|work=Blackfilm.com|title=The Help|accessdate=August 19, 2012|date=August 10, 2011}} [[David Edelstein]] from ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine commented that, "''The Help'' belongs to Viola Davis."{{cite web|last=Edlestein|first=David|url=http://www.vulture.com/2011/08/movie_review_the_help.html|publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|work=Vulture|title=Movie Review: Viola Davis Gives the Too-Soft The Help a Spine|accessdate=August 19, 2012|date=August 10, 2011}} Ida E. Jones, the national director of the [[Association of Black Women Historians]], released an open statement criticizing the film, stating "[d]espite efforts to market the book and the film as a progressive story of triumph over racial injustice, ''The Help'' distorts, ignores, and trivializes the experiences of black domestic workers." The ABWH accused both the book and the film of insensitive portrayals of African-American vernacular, a nearly uniform depiction of black men as cruel or absent, and a failure to acknowledge the sexual harassment that many black women endured in their white employers' homes. Jones concluded by saying that "The Association of Black Women Historians finds it unacceptable for either this book or this film to strip black women's lives of historical accuracy for the sake of entertainment."{{cite web|last=Jones |first=Ida E |date=August 12, 2011 |url=http://truth.abwh.org/2011/08/12/an-open-statement-to-the-fans-of-the-help/ |title=An Open Statement to the Fans of The Help |publisher=[[Association of Black Women Historians]] |accessdate=November 1, 2011}} Roxane Gay of literary web magazine ''[[The Rumpus]]'' argues the film might be offensive to African Americans, saying the film uses racial Hollywood [[Trope (literature)|tropes]] like the [[Magical Negro]] character.{{cite web|last=Gay |first=Roxane |date=August 17, 2011|url=http://therumpus.net/2011/08/the-solace-of-preparing-fried-foods-and-other-quaint-remembrances-from-1960s-mississippi-thoughts-on-the-help |title=The Solace of Preparing Fried Foods and Other Quaint Remembrances from 1960s Mississippi: Thoughts on The Help |work=[[The Rumpus]]|accessdate=November 1, 2011}} In 2014, the movie was one of several discussed by [[Keli Goff]] in ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' in an article concerning [[White savior narrative in film|white savior narratives in film]].{{cite news | last=Goff | first=Keli | url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/05/04/can-belle-end-hollywood-s-obsession-with-the-white-savior.html | title=Can 'Belle' End Hollywood's Obsession with the White Savior? | work=[[The Daily Beast]] | date=May 4, 2014 | accessdate=May 14, 2014 }} ===Box office=== ''The Help'' earned $169,708,112 in North America and $46,931,000 in other territories for a worldwide total of $216,639,112. In North America, on its opening day (Wednesday, August 10, 2011), it topped the box office with $5.54 million. It then added $4.33 million on Thursday, declining only 21 percent, a two-day total to $9.87 million.{{cite web|url = http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3246&p=.htm|title = 'The Help' Bags Solid $9.9M in Two Days|work = [[Box Office Mojo]] |publisher=[[IMDb]]|first=Brandon|last=Gray|date=August 11, 2011|accessdate=June 26, 2018}} On its first weekend, the film grossed $26.0 million, coming in second place behind ''[[Rise of the Planet of the Apes]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3248&p=.htm |title=Weekend Report: 'Apes' Cling to Top Spot, 'Help' Cleans Up|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[IMDb]]|first=Brandon|last=Gray|date=August 15, 2011|accessdate=June 26, 2018}} However, during its second weekend, the film jumped to first place with $20.0 million, declining only 23 percent, the smallest drop among films playing nationwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3255&p=.htm |title=Weekend Report: 'The Help' Reigns Over Gutless 'Conan,' 'Fright Night'|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[IMDb]]|date=August 22, 2011|accessdate=June 26, 2018}} The film crossed the $100 million mark on its 21st day of release, becoming one of only two titles in August 2011 that achieved this.{{cite news|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3263&p=.htm|title=August Box Office Rises and Falls|first=Brandon|last=Gray|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[IMDb]]|date=September 2, 2011|accessdate=September 4, 2011}} On its fourth weekend (Labor Day three-day weekend), it became the first film since ''[[Inception]]'' (2010), to top the box-office charts for three consecutive weekends.{{cite news|url=http://www.newmoviesonnetflix.com/browse-action-new-movies-on-netflix-videos-1-date.html|title=Box Office Report: 'Apollo 18' and 'Shark Night' Still in a Dead Heat|first=Pamela|last=McClintock|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=September 4, 2011|accessdate=September 4, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150111223516/http://www.newmoviesonnetflix.com/browse-action-new-movies-on-netflix-videos-1-date.html#|archive-date=January 11, 2015|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3265&p=.htm |title=Weekend Report: 'The Help' Works It Over Labor Day|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[IMDb]]|first=Brandon|last=Gray|date=September 6, 2011|accessdate=June 26, 2018}} Its four-day weekend haul of $19.9 million{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?view=&yr=2011&wknd=35a&p=|title=September 2–5, 2011|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[IMDb]]|accessdate=September 4, 2011}} was the fourth largest for a Labor-day weekend.{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/alltime/weekends/laborday.htm?page=LAB&p=.htm|title=Top 4-Day Labor Day Weekends|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[IMDb]]|accessdate=September 4, 2011}} Notably, ''The Help'' topped the box office for 25 days in a row. This was the longest uninterrupted streak since ''[[The Sixth Sense]]'' (35 days), which was also a late summer release, in 1999.{{cite news|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3268&p=.htm|title='Help' Posts Longest Daily No. 1 Run Since 'Sixth Sense'|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|publisher=[[IMDb]]|first=Ray|last=Subers|date=September 9, 2011|accessdate=September 4, 2011}} To promote the film, [[TakePart]] hosted a series of three writing contests.{{cite web|title=The Help|work=[[TakePart]]|publisher=[[Participant Media]]|accessdate=June 26, 2018|url=http://takepart.com/thehelp}} Rebecca Lubin, of Mill Valley, California, who has been a nanny for nearly two decades won the recipe contest. Darcy Pattison's "11 Ways to Ruin a Photograph" won "The Help" Children's Story Contest with her story about a tenacious young girl who refuses to take a good photograph while her father is away "soldiering". After being chosen by guest judge and children's-book author [[Lou Berger]], the story was professionally illustrated.{{cite web|title=11 Ways To Ruin a Photograph|url=http://11ways.darcypattison.com|work=11 Ways to Ruin a Photograph|accessdate=June 26, 2018|dead-url=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307232850/http://11ways.darcypattison.com/#|archivedate=March 7, 2012|first=Darcy|last=Pattison|df=mdy-all}} The final contest was about "someone who inspired you". Genoveva Islas-Hooker charmed guest judge Doc Hendley (founder of [[Wine to Water]]) with her story, A Heroine Named Confidential. A case manager for patients with HIV, Islas-Hooker was consistently inspired by one special individual who never gave up the fight to live. ===Accolades=== {{main|List of accolades received by The Help (film)}} At the [[84th Academy Awards]], [[Octavia Spencer]] won the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]] for her role in this film. The film also received three other [[Academy Award]] nominations: [[Academy Award for Best Picture]], [[Academy Award for Best Actress]] for [[Viola Davis]], and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]] for [[Jessica Chastain]].{{cite web|title=Nominees and Winners for the 84th Academy Awards|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/84/nominees.html|work=Oscars.org|publisher=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]]|accessdate=May 20, 2014}} ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = The Help: Music from the Motion Picture | type = Soundtrack | artist = Various artists | cover = | alt = | released = July 26, 2011 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Blues]], [[Soul music|soul]], [[rhythm and blues]], [[rock and roll]] | length = | label = [[Geffen Records|Geffen]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = | misc = {{Singles | name = The Help | type = soundtrack | single1 = [[The Living Proof]] | single1date = August 16, 2011 }} }} The original song is "[[The Living Proof]]" by [[Mary J. Blige]].{{cite web|title=Soundtrack Details For "The Help" (Track List Includes Ray Charles, Chubby Checker + Many Others)|url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/shadowandact/soundtrack_details_for_the_help_track_list_includes_ray_charles_chubby_chec|work=[[IndieWire]]|accessdate=January 30, 2012|date=June 21, 2011|publisher=[[Penske Business Media]]|first=Tambay A.|last=Obenson|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131226230450/http://blogs.indiewire.com/shadowandact/soundtrack_details_for_the_help_track_list_includes_ray_charles_chubby_chec#|archive-date=December 26, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The soundtrack was released on July 26, 2011, through [[Geffen Records]].{{cite web|title=The Help: Music from the Motion Picture|url=https://www.amazon.com/Help-Music-Motion-Picture/dp/B0055FDMRI|publisher=[[Amazon (company)|Amazon]]|accessdate=January 30, 2012|date=July 26, 2011}} {{Track listing |extra_column = Performers |headline = Track listing |title1 = [[The Living Proof]] |length1 = 5:57 |extra1 = [[Mary J. Blige]] |title2 = [[Jackson (song)#Notable covers|Jackson]] |length2 = 5:28 |extra2 = [[Johnny Cash]] and [[June Carter]] |title3 = [[Sherry (song)|Sherry]] |length3 = 5:35 |extra3 = [[Frankie Valli]] |title4 = [[I Ain't Never]] |length4 = 1:56 |extra4 = [[Webb Pierce]] |title5 = Victory Is Mine |length5 = 3:47 |extra5 = [[Dorothy Norwood]] |title6 = [[Road Runner (Bo Diddley song)|Road Runner]] |length6 = 2:48 |extra6 = [[Bo Diddley]] |title7 = [[Hallelujah I Love Her So]] |length7 = 2:35 |extra7 = [[Ray Charles]] |title8 = The Wah-Watusi |length8 = 2:32 |extra8 = [[The Orlons]] |title9 = [[Personality (Lloyd Price song)|Personality]] |length9 = 10:29 |extra9 = [[Lloyd Price]] |title10 = [[Don't Think Twice, It's All Right]] |length10 = 3:38 |extra10 = [[Bob Dylan]] |title11 = [[Let's Twist Again]] |length11 = 2:19 |extra11 = [[Chubby Checker]] |title12 = Don't Knock |length12 = 2:30 |extra12 = [[Mavis Staples]] }} ===Score=== {{Infobox album | name = The Help: Original Motion Picture Score | type = Soundtrack | artist = Thomas Newman | cover = | alt = | released = September 13, 2011 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = | length = 59:34 | label = [[Varèse Sarabande]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} The film's score was composed and conducted by [[Thomas Newman]]; [[Varèse Sarabande]] released a score album on September 13, 2011. {{Track listing |headline = Track listing |title1 = Aibilene |length1 = 3:07 |title2 = Them Fools |length2 = 2:50 |title3 = Upside-Down Cake |length3 = 1:22 |title4 = Mississippi |length4 = 3:50 |title5 = Heart Palpitations |length5 = 1:43 |title6 = The Help |length6 = 2:19 |title7 = Jim Crow |length7 = 1:45 |title8 = Skeeter |length8 = 1:03 |title9 = Miss Hilly |length9 = 1:14 |title10 = Write That Down |length10 = 1:38 |title11 = Bottom Of The List |length11 = 3:23 |title12 = Deviled Eggs |length12 = 2:03 |title13 = First White Baby |length13 = 2:00 |title14 = Celia Digs |length14 = 2:06 |title15 = November 22 |length15 = 1:12 |title16 = Not To Die |length16 = 1:28 |title17 = My Son |length17 = 2:51 |title18 = Trash On The Road |length18 = 1:37 |title19 = The Terrible Awful
